comment.text: Regressions and Performance tests PASSED
default & performance tests pass (KVM)

Seems to work fine on bare-metal HP Z440, AMD RX570 with UEFI. Kernel regression tests both PASS, [Bug 2252130](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2252130) still present but OpenCL compute now working [albeit with trace errors](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/drm/amd/-/issues/3007).

Seems to be working fine.

Intel NUC NUC13ANHi7 (NUC13ANHi7000) (rev N11225-207) 1 x 13th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-1360P
Intel Corporation Raptor Lake-P [Iris Xe Graphics] (rev 04)

Works for me. The enabled Default and Performance tests pass OK.  
Work Station, Asus prime mobo - Ryzen5 5600g/AMDGPU, 400 Series Chipset, (UEFI) Secure boot, SSD's > RAID1 (ext4) running Plasma6 DE.
Framework laptop 13 AMD 7840U GNOME Wayland; no regressions.
default & performance tests pass (KVM)
Tests pass on POWER9 / ppc64le. Seems okay so far.

Wifi not work, the same problem with all Kernel 6.7.x version I tried. I return to 6.6.14-200.fc39.x86_64 and wifi works fine. Realtek BrosTrend USB external and Broadcom internal. System Acer Aspire E1-571

Device: Asus X541N laptop with Fedora LXQt

compare kernel 6.5.6 with this update:

- system lags
- streaming  youtube videos keeps buffering

revert back to kernel 6.5.6

Also, test regression result: Warn

Performance test: Pass

Hopefully, future updates will solve these problem or else, I cannot be able to use Fedora anymore with my old laptop, even installing Fedora with the liightest Fedora Spin
Works on baremetal (non UEFI mode) AMD Ryzen5 3600, Mainboard MSI B450M Mortar Max with prop. nvidia driver (550.54.14) from rpmfusion.org (RTX3070 card). Works with Gnome-Desktop (Xorg).
Works just fine on my simple rig.  I don't use suspend or bluetooth.  Ryzen 3700x and Nvidia from rpmfusion.
Works for me.
Working fine in a VirtualBox VM.
shutdown hangs in black screen, need to force shutdown
Lenovo Thinkpad P16s AMD Gen2. regression tests ok and uploaded. modern standby suspend and resume ok. wifi ok. seems all is working fine on that kernel.

bugs.title: CVE-2024-22099 kernel: NULL Pointer dereference  bluetooth allows Overflow Buffers

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-22099 kernel: NULL Pointer dereference  bluetooth allows Overflow Buffers

long_desc.thetext:
NULL Pointer Dereference vulnerability in Linux Linux kernel kernel on Linux, x86, ARM (net, bluetooth modules) allows Overflow Buffers. This vulnerability is associated with program files /net/bluetooth/rfcomm/core.C.

Refer:
https://bugzilla.openanolis.cn/show_bug.cgi?id=7956
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/bluetooth/bluetooth-next.git/commit/?id=6ec00b0737fe

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2267702]

bugs.title: TRIAGE CVE-2024-22099 kernel: NULL Pointer dereference  bluetooth allows Overflow Buffers [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: TRIAGE CVE-2024-22099 kernel: NULL Pointer dereference  bluetooth allows Overflow Buffers [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2024-22099 kernel: NULL Pointer dereference  bluetooth allows Overflow Buffers

long_desc.thetext:
NULL Pointer Dereference vulnerability in Linux Linux kernel kernel on Linux, x86, ARM (net, bluetooth modules) allows Overflow Buffers. This vulnerability is associated with program files /net/bluetooth/rfcomm/core.C.

Refer:
https://bugzilla.openanolis.cn/show_bug.cgi?id=7956
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/bluetooth/bluetooth-next.git/commit/?id=6ec00b0737fe

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2267702]

More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

http://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2267701

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=medium

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=2267701,2267702

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new

bugs.title: CVE-2024-26622 kernel: tomoyo: fix UAF write bug in tomoyo_write_control()

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-26622 kernel: tomoyo: fix UAF write bug in tomoyo_write_control()

long_desc.thetext:
In the Linux kernel, the following vulnerability has been resolved:

tomoyo: fix UAF write bug in tomoyo_write_control()

The Linux kernel CVE team has assigned CVE-2024-26622 to this issue.

Upstream advisory:
https://lore.kernel.org/linux-cve-announce/2024030409-CVE-2024-26622-9e01@gregkh/

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2267722]

The result of automatic check (that is developed by Alexander Larkin) for this CVE-2024-26622 is: 	SKIP	No affected files built, so skip this CVE	NO			-	-	unknown (where first YES/NO value means if related sources built).
